introduction.hook: When SolarWinds was breached in 2020, the attackers operated undetected for NINE MONTHS inside thousands of organizations including US government agencies and Fortune 500 companies. Why did traditional security tools miss it? Because they relied primarily on IOCs - indicators of KNOWN threats - and these attackers used novel techniques with no existing signatures. The attackers even named their malware to blend with legitimate SolarWinds files. This breach proved that effective detection requires understanding both IOCs (evidence of what happened) and IOAs (behavior patterns of what's happening) - combining signature-based detection with behavioral analysis to catch threats before catastrophic damage occurs.
learning_goals: Distinguish between Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) and Indicators of Attack (IOAs)
Identify common IOC types and their strengths/limitations
Compare detection methods: signature, anomaly, and behavioral analysis
Apply threat intelligence to improve detection capabilities
Understand SIEM correlation and detection engineering
introduction.why_it_matters: Detection is the difference between a minor security incident and a catastrophic breach. Organizations with strong detection capabilities identify breaches in days; those without may not know for months or years.
introduction.exam_weight: Detection and indicator concepts appear in approximately 6-8% of Security+ exam questions

sections.title: Indicators of Compromise (IOCs)
sections.content: IOCs are forensic artifacts that indicate a system has been compromised - the digital fingerprints and evidence attackers leave behind. Common IOC types include file hashes (MD5, SHA1, SHA256) that uniquely identify malicious files, IP addresses of command-and-control servers, domain names used in attacks, URLs hosting malware, registry key modifications, mutex names used by malware for persistence, and email artifacts like sender addresses and subject lines. IOCs are reactive by nature - they help you detect KNOWN threats after security researchers have analyzed attacks and published indicators. The critical limitation: attackers constantly change indicators. An IP address used today will be different tomorrow. A file hash changes with the slightest modification. This is why IOC-only detection has limited effectiveness against sophisticated adversaries who rotate infrastructure frequently.
key_points: IOCs are evidence of compromise: file hashes, IPs, domains, URLs, registry keys, mutexes, email artifacts
File hashes (SHA256 preferred) uniquely identify specific malicious files - any change creates new hash
Network IOCs (IPs, domains) have high churn rate - attackers rotate infrastructure constantly
IOCs are reactive - they detect KNOWN threats only, after analysis and publication
Threat intelligence feeds provide continuously updated IOC lists from security community

mnemonics.mnemonic: FIND-HIM = File hashes, IP addresses, Network traffic, Domains, Hash values, Indicators, Mutexes

mnemonics.explanation: IOCs only detect previously documented indicators

analogies.analogy: IOCs are like wanted posters at the post office. They help you identify known criminals, but they're useless against someone who's never been photographed or who's wearing a disguise.

common_mistakes.mistake: Relying solely on IOCs for threat detection
common_mistakes.why_wrong: IOCs are reactive - they only detect KNOWN threats after security researchers have analyzed and published them. Zero-days, novel attacks, and sophisticated adversaries who rotate infrastructure won't have published IOCs.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Layer IOCs (known bad indicators) with behavioral analysis (suspicious activity patterns) for comprehensive detection that catches both known and unknown threats.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: IOCs detect known threats; behavioral analysis is needed for unknown threats

common_mistakes.mistake: Treating all IOC matches as confirmed compromises
common_mistakes.why_wrong: IOCs have false positive issues. Shared hosting means a malicious IP may also host legitimate sites. CDNs serve both good and bad content from same IPs. Old IOCs become stale but may still trigger.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: IOC matches are indicators requiring investigation, not automatic confirmations. Correlate with other evidence before declaring compromise.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: IOC matches require validation - they're indicators, not proof

real_world_example.scenario: A SOC receives 150 alerts daily from IOC matches against threat feeds. Investigation reveals 90% are false positives - old indicators, shared infrastructure, or legitimate services on flagged IPs. They implement confidence scoring and correlation requirements.
real_world_example.application: By requiring correlation with other suspicious activity before alerting, they reduced false positives by 85% while maintaining detection of real threats.

what_would_happen_if: If you rely only on IOCs: You'll miss novel attacks, zero-days, and sophisticated adversaries who rotate infrastructure
If you don't validate IOC matches: You'll waste analyst time on false positives and potentially miss real threats hidden in alert fatigue

knowledge_check.question: Why can't organizations rely solely on IOCs for comprehensive threat detection?
options: A. IOCs are too expensive to implement
B. IOCs only detect known threats and can't catch novel attacks or zero-days
C. IOCs require too much storage space
D. IOCs only work on Windows systems
knowledge_check.explanation: IOCs are documentation of past attacks. New attack techniques, zero-days, and novel malware won't have published IOCs until after they're discovered and analyzed by researchers.

wrong_answer_analysis.A: Many IOC feeds are free; cost isn't the limitation
wrong_answer_analysis.C: IOCs are typically small text entries; storage isn't an issue
wrong_answer_analysis.D: IOCs work across all platforms - IPs and domains are platform-agnostic

must_remember_for_exam: IOCs are reactive - known threats only
File hashes identify specific files; any change = new hash

glossary_terms.definition: Indicator of Compromise - forensic evidence that a system may have been breached
A cryptographic fingerprint (MD5, SHA1, SHA256) that uniquely identifies a specific file
A stream of IOC data from security researchers and organizations
Infrastructure used by attackers to communicate with and control compromised systems

sections.title: Indicators of Attack (IOAs)
sections.content: While IOCs tell you what happened (forensic evidence), IOAs tell you what's happening (behavioral patterns). IOAs focus on attacker ACTIONS and BEHAVIORS regardless of the specific tools, infrastructure, or malware used. Examples include: reconnaissance behavior (port scanning, directory enumeration), credential theft attempts (password spraying, Kerberoasting), privilege escalation patterns (exploiting misconfigurations, token manipulation), lateral movement (remote service access, PsExec usage), data staging (compression before exfiltration), and command-and-control patterns (beaconing behavior, unusual protocols). Because IOAs focus on behavior rather than specific indicators, they can detect novel attacks without pre-existing signatures. The attacker must perform certain actions to achieve objectives - IOAs detect those actions. This maps directly to frameworks like MITRE ATT&CK, which catalogs adversary tactics and techniques.
key_points: IOAs focus on attacker BEHAVIOR and ACTIONS, not specific artifacts or tools
Can detect novel attacks without pre-existing signatures by identifying suspicious patterns
Maps to MITRE ATT&CK tactics: Reconnaissance, Initial Access, Execution, Persistence, etc.
Examples: credential theft patterns, lateral movement, data staging, beaconing behavior
Requires understanding of normal vs abnormal behavior in your environment (baseline)

mnemonics.mnemonic: IOC = What HAPPENED (evidence), IOA = What's HAPPENING (behavior)
mnemonics.explanation: Past tense vs present tense detection

mnemonics.mnemonic: Behavior beats Signatures for unknown threats

analogies.analogy: If IOCs are wanted posters (identifying known criminals by appearance), IOAs are behavioral profiling (identifying criminal BEHAVIOR like casing a bank, regardless of who's doing it or what they look like).

common_mistakes.why_wrong: IOCs are specific artifacts (a particular IP address, a specific file hash). IOAs are behavioral patterns (lateral movement, credential dumping) that could be performed by any tool.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: IOCs identify specific known-bad items. IOAs identify suspicious behavioral patterns regardless of the tools used.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: IOCs are things (artifacts); IOAs are actions (behaviors)

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking IOAs replace the need for IOCs
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Both provide value. IOCs quickly catch known threats with high confidence. IOAs catch unknown threats but may have more false positives. Layered detection uses both.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Use IOCs for fast, high-confidence detection of known threats AND IOAs for behavioral detection of unknown threats. Defense in depth.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Best detection combines both IOCs and IOAs

real_world_example.scenario: An organization's IOC-based detection missed a novel attack because the malware had never been seen before. However, their behavioral detection (IOA) caught the attack when it detected: unusual PowerShell execution, credential access attempts, lateral movement via WMI, and data compression on a file server.
real_world_example.application: The behavioral detection caught what signature-based detection missed because it focused on WHAT the attacker was doing, not the specific tools they used.

what_would_happen_if: If you only use IOCs: You'll miss custom malware, zero-days, and living-off-the-land attacks that use legitimate tools
If you don't baseline normal behavior: You can't detect anomalies - you won't know what's suspicious without knowing what's normal

knowledge_check.question: How can IOAs detect attacks that have no published IOCs?
options: A. IOAs use more advanced signature databases
B. IOAs focus on behavioral patterns that attackers must perform regardless of tools used
C. IOAs scan more thoroughly than IOC-based detection
D. IOAs use artificial intelligence to guess new IOCs
knowledge_check.explanation: Attackers must perform certain actions (reconnaissance, credential access, lateral movement) to achieve objectives. IOAs detect these behavioral patterns regardless of specific tools or infrastructure.

wrong_answer_analysis.A: IOAs aren't signature-based - that's the whole point of behavioral detection
wrong_answer_analysis.C: Thoroughness isn't the differentiator; behavioral focus is
wrong_answer_analysis.D: IOAs detect behavior, not predict specific indicators

must_remember_for_exam: IOAs detect behavioral patterns, not specific artifacts
IOAs can catch novel attacks without signatures
Use both IOCs AND IOAs for comprehensive detection

glossary_terms.definition: Indicator of Attack - behavioral patterns that indicate an attack in progress
Technique where attackers move from one compromised system to others within a network
Regular communication pattern from compromised systems to command-and-control servers
Attack technique using legitimate system tools instead of malware to avoid detection

sections.title: Detection Methods and Technologies
sections.content: Three primary detection approaches form the foundation of security monitoring, each with distinct strengths and weaknesses. Signature-based detection matches known patterns - fast and accurate for documented threats but completely blind to zero-days and novel attacks. It's like antivirus: great for known malware, useless for new variants. Anomaly-based detection establishes behavioral baselines and alerts on statistical deviations - can catch novel threats but generates significant false positives as legitimate unusual activity triggers alerts. Machine learning improves accuracy but requires extensive tuning. Behavioral analysis (heuristic detection) looks for sequences of actions matching attack patterns rather than single anomalies - more context-aware than pure anomaly detection. Modern detection strategies layer all three: signatures for known threats (high confidence, low overhead), anomaly detection for unusual activity (catches unknowns, needs tuning), and behavioral analysis for attack pattern recognition (balances coverage and accuracy).
key_points: Signature-based: Fast, accurate for known threats, zero false positives for good signatures, but blind to zero-days
Anomaly-based: Establishes normal baseline, alerts on deviations, catches novel threats, higher false positives
Behavioral/Heuristic: Detects action sequences matching attack patterns, balances coverage with accuracy
Layer all three approaches for defense in depth
SIEM correlates events across sources to detect multi-stage attacks

mnemonics.explanation: Signature detection is blind to novel threats

analogies.analogy: Signature = checking IDs against a wanted list. Anomaly = noticing someone behaving differently than the crowd. Behavioral = recognizing that someone casing a building, checking exits, and carrying tools matches a burglar pattern.

common_mistakes.mistake: Expecting signature-based detection to catch zero-days
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Signatures detect KNOWN patterns. By definition, zero-days are unknown - no signature exists until after discovery, analysis, and publication. That takes days to weeks.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Zero-day detection requires behavioral analysis, anomaly detection, sandboxing, or heuristics - methods that don't require prior knowledge of the specific threat.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Signature-based detection cannot detect zero-day attacks

common_mistakes.mistake: Setting anomaly detection thresholds too sensitive
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Overly sensitive thresholds generate excessive false positives, causing alert fatigue. Analysts start ignoring alerts, missing real threats hidden in the noise.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Balance sensitivity with specificity. Start with conservative thresholds, tune based on environment. Better to miss some anomalies than drown in false positives.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Alert fatigue from false positives reduces detection effectiveness

real_world_example.scenario: A SOC implemented aggressive anomaly detection with default thresholds. They received 2,000 alerts daily, causing analysts to ignore most alerts. When a real breach occurred, the alerts were lost in the noise and went uninvestigated for 3 weeks.
real_world_example.application: After tuning thresholds and implementing correlation requirements, they reduced alerts to 50/day with 40% true positive rate - still catching threats but with manageable volume.

what_would_happen_if: If you rely only on signatures: You'll have a false sense of security while zero-days and novel attacks compromise your systems
If anomaly thresholds are too sensitive: Alert fatigue will cause analysts to miss real attacks buried in false positives

knowledge_check.question: What type of detection method can identify a zero-day exploit?
options: A. Signature-based detection with updated rules
C. Pattern matching with comprehensive databases
knowledge_check.explanation: Zero-days have no existing signatures by definition. Detection relies on identifying abnormal behavior or deviations from established baselines rather than matching known patterns.

wrong_answer_analysis.A: You can't update signatures for something that hasn't been discovered yet
wrong_answer_analysis.C: Pattern matching is signature-based and requires known patterns
wrong_answer_analysis.D: Hash scanning only identifies known malicious files

must_remember_for_exam: Anomaly detection = catches unknown but has false positives

glossary_terms.definition: Detection method that matches known patterns of malicious activity
Detection method that identifies deviations from established normal behavior
Detection method that identifies suspicious patterns based on rules and behaviors
Desensitization to alerts due to excessive false positives, leading to missed threats

sections.title: SIEM and Threat Intelligence Integration
sections.content: The SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) is the central nervous system of security operations, collecting logs from across the environment, normalizing data formats, correlating events, and generating actionable alerts. Effective SIEM deployment requires thoughtful architecture: determine what log sources to collect (prioritize security-relevant sources), ensure adequate storage and processing capacity, create meaningful correlation rules that detect attacks rather than just anomalies, and continuously tune to reduce false positives. Threat intelligence integration transforms raw IOCs into automated detection: commercial feeds provide curated indicators, ISACs (Information Sharing and Analysis Centers) share industry-specific threats, open source feeds (AlienVault OTX, Abuse.ch) provide community intelligence, and government sources (CISA) share national-level threats. The key is curation - not all indicators are relevant to your environment, and old indicators create noise.
key_points: SIEM core functions: Collect logs, Normalize formats, Correlate events, Alert on threats, Report metrics
Log sources prioritization: authentication, network flow, endpoint, email, cloud, application logs
Correlation rules combine multiple events to detect attack patterns (single events may be benign)
Threat intel sources: Commercial feeds, ISACs, OSINT (OTX, Abuse.ch), Government (CISA)
Feed curation is essential: filter for relevance, set confidence scores, age out old indicators

mnemonics.mnemonic: CNCAR = Collect, Normalize, Correlate, Alert, Report

analogies.analogy: Individual puzzle pieces (events) may seem meaningless. SIEM correlation assembles the pieces into a picture (attack). A failed login + successful login + lateral movement + data access = detected breach, but each piece alone looks innocent.

common_mistakes.mistake: Importing threat feeds without curation or tuning
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Uncurated feeds generate excessive alerts from old indicators, irrelevant threats, and false positives. This creates noise that obscures real threats.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Filter feeds for relevance to your environment, set confidence thresholds, age out old indicators, and continuously tune based on false positive rates.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Threat intelligence requires curation and tuning to be effective

common_mistakes.mistake: Using SIEM for log storage without correlation
common_mistakes.why_wrong: SIEM value comes from correlation - combining events across sources to detect patterns. Without correlation, you just have expensive log storage.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Build correlation rules that detect attack patterns. Single event alerts are less valuable than multi-event correlations that reveal attack chains.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: SIEM value is in correlation, not just log collection

real_world_example.scenario: A company deployed SIEM but only collected Windows event logs and imported 15 threat feeds without tuning. Result: 5,000 daily alerts, mostly false positives, and they missed a breach that came through their Linux servers (not monitored).
real_world_example.application: After expanding log sources, tuning feeds, and building correlation rules, they reduced alerts to 200/day with 60% true positive rate and full environment visibility.

what_would_happen_if: If you don't correlate events: You'll see individual trees but miss the forest - single events may look benign while the attack pattern goes undetected
If you import all threat feeds without tuning: You'll drown in alerts from irrelevant or outdated indicators while real threats hide in the noise

knowledge_check.question: Why is event correlation essential in a SIEM rather than just alerting on individual events?
options: B. Single events may appear benign while the pattern across events reveals an attack
C. Correlation is required for compliance
D. It makes the SIEM faster
knowledge_check.explanation: A failed login, a successful login, lateral movement, and data access might each seem innocent alone. Correlated together, they reveal an attack in progress.

wrong_answer_analysis.C: While compliance may require SIEM, correlation's value is detection effectiveness
wrong_answer_analysis.D: Correlation actually requires more processing, not less

must_remember_for_exam: SIEM: Collect, Normalize, Correlate, Alert, Report
Correlation detects patterns that single events miss
Threat feeds require curation and tuning

glossary_terms.definition: Security Information and Event Management - centralized platform for log collection, correlation, and alerting
Information Sharing and Analysis Center - industry-specific threat intelligence sharing organization
SIEM logic that combines multiple events to detect attack patterns
Converting logs from different formats into a standard schema for analysis

hands_on_activity.title: IOC Analysis Exercise
hands_on_activity.description: Given a set of IOCs from a threat intelligence report, categorize them by type, assess their useful lifespan, and design detection rules.

what_would_you_do.scenario: Your threat feed alerts on an IP address communicating with 50 internal hosts. Investigation shows it's a legitimate cloud service your marketing team uses. However, the same feed has been accurate for other threats.
discussion_points: How do you balance security with business operations?
Should you whitelist or tune the feed?
How do you prevent this scenario in the future?

key_takeaways: IOCs detect known threats (reactive); IOAs detect behavioral patterns (proactive)
Layer signature, anomaly, and behavioral detection for comprehensive coverage
SIEM correlation turns individual events into detected attack patterns
Threat intelligence requires curation - not all feeds are relevant to your environment
Zero-days require behavioral/anomaly detection since no signatures exist
exam_tips: IOC = Indicator of Compromise (evidence/artifact), IOA = Indicator of Attack (behavior/action)
Signature-based catches known threats only; behavioral catches unknown
SIEM value is in correlation, not just log storage
Alert fatigue from false positives is a real detection problem
Know detection limitation: signatures cannot detect zero-days
